title: Typeface REVISIONS
content:
Hi again everyone,

i am looking at the way old typefaces have been tweaked to form new, revised versions of themselves, by either varying their x-heights or contrasts etc. I am also interested to find out what typefaces have been influenced by older typefaces in that they look very similiar to the old one but are not part of it.

Can anyone share some examples of type that has been tweaked?  
many thanx !
author: blakkdoll

comments.content: This isn't a particularly savory example, but [Klavika](http://web.archive.org/web/20110105031946/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Klavika) was reborn as [Sentico Sans](http://web.archive.org/web/20110105031946/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/dtptypes/sentico-sans-dt/).

Proxima Sans / Proxima Nova  
Optima / Optima Nova

Is that the kind of thing you're looking for?

Aldus and Palatino served two different purposes, but it is an example.

Optima and Optima Nova is an example of a 50+ year revisit, augmentation, expansion and adjustment for technology. And OH what a revision! He added titling as well as condensed faces. In the calligraphic field we would refer to it as a master stroke of genius.  
Michael

About Optima Nova, dont forget the exquisite new italic. also, Frutiger \> Frutiger Next, Avenir \> Avenir Next, and Baskerville \> Mrs Eaves, to a certain extent.

And of course, Frutiger \> Myriad... no! NO! I'M KIDDING! DON'T SHOOT! DON'T SHOO \*paw\* \*paw\* aargh

:-)  
dr

Stephen, you are too kind. Sentico is so obviously appropriated from Klavika.

Some of the DTP types are another matter entirely, as they combine shapes and letters from a variety of existing faces, seemingly to mask their derivative basis. At best, these might be called collages.

Your question opens a [familiar can of worms.](http://web.archive.org/web/20110105031946/http:/typophile.com/node/45435)
